contexts: MQInput node This node provides message input to a message flow from a WebSphere MQ message queue defined on the broker queue manager. Properties navigator This displays the node properties. Configure the node by selecting the properties and setting their values. Mandatory properties are marked with an asterisk. Description page If you want to describe the purpose of the node in the message flow, use these fields to enter a short description, a long description, or both. Basic page Enter the name of the queue from which the message flow receives messages. Basic page Configure the connection details to enable a message to be received from a queue on a remote queue manager if not using a default queue manager on the target Integration Node Input Message Parsing page Set properties that describe the message domain, message set, message type, and message format that the node uses to determine how the incoming message is parsed. Parser Options page Edit the timing properties on this page to control when and how messages are parsed and validated. Set values for the properties that determine how the request parameters are constructed. Advanced page Set properties that determine how the message is processed: for example, its transactional characteristics and order of retrieval. Validation page Set values for these properties if you want the MRM parser to validate the body of messages using the dictionary generated from the message set. Security page Set values for these properties if you want to configure a security token for use in message flow security. General Message Options page Edit the properties on this page to control when and how messages are parsed and validated. XMLNSC Parser Options page Set values for the properties that determine how the request parameters are constructed. --> Instances page Set values for the properties that control the additional instances that are available for a node. MQOutput node This node delivers an output message from a message flow to a WebSphere MQ queue. Properties navigator This displays the node properties. Configure the node by selecting the properties and setting their values. Mandatory properties are marked with an asterisk. Description page If you want to describe the purpose of the node in the message flow, use these fields to enter a short description, a long description, or both. Basic page Use these fields to enter the queue name to specify the destination of output messages. Do this only if you set destination mode to queue name on the Advanced page. If you select another option for Destination Mode, you do not have to set these properties. MQ Connection page Configure the connection details to enable a message to be sent to a queue on a remote queue manager if not using a default queue manager on the target Integration Node Advanced page Set these properties to define transaction control for the message, and how the message is put to the queue. Optionally, specify an object queue manager name to route messages from the queue manager that is connected to the MQOutput node, to a second queue manager. This option assumes that the MQ channels and transmission queues are configured for the two queue managers. For more information about object queue managers, see: http://pic.dhe.ibm.com/infocenter/wmqv7/v7r5/topic/com.ibm.mq.ref.dev.doc/q098190_.htm. Request page Set these properties to define the characteristics of each output message generated. Validation page Set these properties if you want the MRM parser to validate the body of messages using the dictionary generated from the message set. MQReply node This node sends a response to the originator of the input message. Properties navigator This displays the node properties. Configure the node by selecting the properties and setting their values. Mandatory properties are marked with an asterisk. MQ Connection page Configure the connection details to enable a message to be sent to a queue on a remote queue manager if not using a default queue manager on the target Integration Node Description page If you want to describe the purpose of the node in the message flow, use these fields to enter a short description, a long description, or both. Advanced page Select the Segmentation allowed check box to allow the message to be broken into segments in the queue manager. Use Persistence mode to define whether the output message is marked as persistent when it is put to the output queue, and Transaction mode to define whether the message is written under syncpoint. Validation page Set these properties if you want the MRM parser to validate the body of messages using the dictionary generated from the message set. MQGet node This node receives messages from clients that connect to the broker using the WebSphere MQ Enterprise Transport, and that use the MQI and AMI application programming interfaces. Properties navigator This displays the node properties. Configure the node by selecting the properties and setting their values. Mandatory properties are marked with an asterisk. Description page If you want to describe the purpose of the node in the message flow, use these fields to enter a short description, a long description, or both. Basic page Enter the name of the queue from which the message flow receives messages. Basic page Configure the connection details to enable a message to be received from a queue on a remote queue manager if not using a default queue manager on the target Integration Node Input Message Parsing page Set values for the properties that describe the message domain, message set, message type, and message format that the node uses to determine how to parse the queue message. Parser Options page Edit the timing properties on this page to control when and how messages are parsed and validated. Set values for the properties that determine how the request parameters are constructed. Advanced page Set these properties to define the structure of the output message, and the transactional characteristics of how this message is handled. Request page Set these properties to determine how the request parameters are constructed. Result page Set these properties to determine how the results of the MQGet call are handled. Validation page Set these properties if you want the MRM parser to validate the body of messages using the dictionary generated from the message set. MQOptimizedFlow node The MQOptimizedFlow node is deprecated. The node is a complete message flow that provides a high-performance publish/subscribe message flow. It consists of an MQInput node connected to a Publication node and uses the JMS over WebSphere MQ transport. Properties navigator This displays the node properties. Configure the node by selecting the properties and setting their values. Mandatory properties are marked with an asterisk. Description page If you want to describe the purpose of the node in the message flow, use these fields to enter a short description, a long description, or both. Basic page Enter the name of the queue from which the message flow receives messages. Advanced page Set the Transaction mode property to Yes (the default) if you want the incoming message to be received under syncpoint. MQeInput node This node provides message input to a message flow from a specified bridge queue on the broker's WebSphere MQ Everyplace queue manager. The MQeInput node is deprecated. Replace it with an MQInput node coordinated with your MQe Gateway configuration. Properties navigator This displays the node properties. Configure the node by selecting the properties and setting their values. Mandatory properties are marked with an asterisk. Description page If you want to describe the purpose of the node in the message flow, use these fields to enter a short description, a long description, or both. Default page Set properties that describe the message domain, message set, message type, and message format that the node uses to determine how the incoming message is parsed, and the default topic associated with the message. General page Set the various properties displayed. Use a configuration file only if you must specify additional properties for the node. If the properties on the page are sufficient for your needs, do not select the Use config file check box. Channel page Set the maximum number of channels supported by WebSphere MQ Everyplace in Max channels. The default is zero, which means that there is no limit. Registry page Select the type of registry you require from the drop down list. If you select FileRegistry, you must use the Directory field to specify where the file containing registry and security information is located. If you select PrivateRegistry, you must complete the security parameter fields. Listener page Set properties that define the connection type for WebSphere MQ Everyplace. Set Hostname to the special value "localhost" or to the TCP/IP address 127.0.0.1 (the default value), both of which resolve correctly to the hostname of the server to which the message flow is deployed. MQeOutput node This node forwards messages to a WebSphere MQ Everyplace queue manager. The MQeOutput node is deprecated. Replace it with an MQOutput node coordinated with your MQe Gateway configuration. Properties navigator This displays the node properties. Configure the node by selecting the properties and setting their values. Mandatory properties are marked with an asterisk. Description page If you want to describe the purpose of the node in the message flow, use these fields to enter a short description, a long description, or both. Basic page Use these fields to enter the queue manager name and queue name to specify the destination of output messages. You need to do this only if you set Destination mode to Queue Name on the Advanced page. If you select another option for Destination Mode, you do not have to set these properties. Advanced page Identifies the queue to which the output message is delivered. If you select Queue Name, the message is sent the queue named on the Basic page. If you select Reply to Queue, the message is sent to the queue named in the ReplyToQ field in the MQMD. Selecting Destination List sends the message to the list of queues named in the LocalEnvironment. Request page Set these properties to define the characteristics of each output message generated. JMSInput node This node receives messages from a JMS destination. JMS destinations are accessed through a connection to a JMS provider. Properties navigator This displays the node properties. Configure the node by selecting the properties and setting their values. Mandatory properties are marked with an asterisk. Description page If you want to describe the purpose of the node in the message flow, use these fields to enter a short description, a long description, or both. Basic page Select Source queue if the node is to read from a JMS queue, or Subscription topic for the node to operate in the publish/subscribe domain only. The two modes are mutually exclusive. JMS Connection page Enter the values required to set up the JMS provider connection. Input Message Parsing page Set values for the properties that describe the message domain, message set, message type, and message format. Parser Options page Edit the timing properties on this page to control when and how messages are parsed and validated. Set values for the properties that determine how the request parameters are constructed. Message Selectors page If message filtering is required, set these properties to specify how messages are filtered. Advanced page Set the Transaction mode to define whether the message is received under syncpoint. Validation page Set these properties if you want the MRM parser to validate the body of messages using the dictionary generated from the message set. Security page Set values for the properties that control the authentication, authorization, and propagation of an identity of a message. JMSOutput node This node sends messages to a JMS destination, acting as a JMS message producer. Properties navigator This displays the node properties. Configure the node by selecting the properties and setting their values. Mandatory properties are marked with an asterisk. Description page If you want to describe the purpose of the node in the message flow, use these fields to enter a short description, a long description, or both. Basic page If the node is to be used to subscribe to a topic, enter the name of the Publication Topic. If it is to be used to receive point-to-point messages, enter the Destination queue for the JMS queue name that is listed in the JNDI bindings. The Reply to destination can be either a subscription queue or a Destination topic. JMS Connection page Enter the values required to set up the JMS provider connection. Advanced page Set these properties to define the transactional control for the message and the way the message is put on the queue. Validation page Set these properties if you want the MRM parser to validate the body of messages using the dictionary generated from the message set. CORBARequest node This node calls an external CORBA application over Internet Inter-Orb Protocol (IIOP). Properties navigator This view displays the node properties. Configure the node by selecting the properties and setting their values. Mandatory properties are marked with an asterisk. Description page If you want to describe the purpose of the node in the message flow, use these fields to enter a short description, a long description, or both. Basic page Choose a CORBA IDL file by dragging a CORBA IDL file onto the node, clicking Browse, or typing the file name. Configure the other properties shown. Request page Enter the location for data retrieval. Result page Enter the location to which the node sends output and choose whether to copy to the local environment. Response Message Parsing page Set values for the properties that describe the message domain, message set, message type, and message format that the node uses to determine how to parse the incoming message. Monitoring page Add, edit, or delete the monitoring events for a node. Enable or disable monitoring events by selecting or clearing the check box. JMSReply node This node sends JMS messages only to the reply destination that is supplied in the JMSReplyTo header field of the JMS message tree. If you have no other routing requirement you can use this node to treat a JMS message output from a message flow as a reply to a JMS input message. Properties navigator This displays the node properties. Configure the node by selecting the properties and setting their values. Mandatory properties are marked with an asterisk. Description page If you want to describe the purpose of the node in the message flow, use these fields to enter a short description, a long description, or both. Basic page Select the Send to destination list in local environment check box to send a JMS meesage to the JMS destination list built in the LocalEnvironment. If you do not select this check box, the node uses the configured JMS destination. JMS Connection page Set these properties to select a JMS vendor and to specify the file system path for the bindings file or its LDAP location. Advanced page Set these properties to define the transactional characteristics of the message and its degree of persistence. Validation page Set values to determine whether validation of the output message takes place, and what actions are taken if the message fails. JMSMQTransform node This node transforms a JMS message into a WebSphere MQ JMS message. Properties navigator This displays the node properties. Configure the node by selecting the properties and setting their values. Mandatory properties are marked with an asterisk. Description page If you want to describe the purpose of the node in the message flow, use these fields to enter a short description, a long description, or both. MQJMSTransform node This node transforms a WebSphere MQ JMS message into a JMS message. Properties navigator This displays the node properties. Configure the node by selecting the properties and setting their values. Mandatory properties are marked with an asterisk. Description page If you want to describe the purpose of the node in the message flow, use these fields to enter a short description, a long description, or both. HTTPInput node This node receives Web service requests. If you include an HTTPInput node in a message flow, you must also include an HTTPReply node in the same flow. Properties navigator This displays the node properties. Configure the node by selecting the properties and setting their values. Mandatory properties are marked with an asterisk. Description page If you want to describe the purpose of the node in the message flow, use these fields to enter a short description, a long description, or both. Basic page In the Path suffix for URL field, specify the path part (not the full URL) of the URL from which this node receives Web service requests. Input Message Parsing page Set values for the properties that describe the message domain, message set, message type, and message format that the node uses to determine how to parse the incoming message. Parser Options page Edit the timing properties on this page to control when and how messages are parsed and validated. Set values for the properties that determine how the request parameters are constructed. Error Handling page Enter the Maximum client wait time timeout interval. This is the length of time that the TCP/IP listener waits for a response from the HTTPReply node in the message flow. Set the Fault Format to SOAP 1.1, SOAP 1.2 or HTML. Validation page Set these properties if you want the MRM parser to validate the body of messages using the dictionary generated from the message set. Security page Set values for these properties if you want to configure a security token for use in message flow security. Advanced page Select Set destination list if you want to add the method binding name to the RouteToLabel destination list; add a label prefix if you need to distinguish between multiple input nodes in the same message flow. Select Parse Query String in order to parse and decode any incoming query string into the Local Environment QueryString folder. HTTPReply node This node returns a response from the message flow to the web services client. This node generates the response to the Web service client from which the input message was received by the HTTPInput node. Properties navigator This displays the node properties. Configure the node by selecting the properties and setting their values. Mandatory properties are marked with an asterisk. Description page If you want to describe the purpose of the node in the message flow, use these fields to enter a short description, a long description, or both. Basic page Set these properties to configure the HTTPReply node. Unless you select Ignore transport failures you must supply a value for Reply send timeout. Validation page Set these properties if you want the MRM parser to validate the body of messages using the dictionary generated from the message set. HTTPRequest node This node interacts with a Web service, using all or part of the input message as the request to that service. This node modifies the input message with all, or part of the content, of the Web service response before propagating the message to subsequent nodes in the message flow. Properties navigator This displays the node properties. Configure the node by selecting the properties and setting their values. Mandatory properties are marked with an asterisk. Description page If you want to describe the purpose of the node in the message flow, use these fields to enter a short description, a long description, or both. Basic page Select the URL for the Web service to which the node sends a request and set the value of the Request Timeout property, which is the length of time, in seconds, that the node waits for a response from the Web service. HTTP Settings page Set the location of the proxy server to which requests are sent and specify how the node should handle Web service responses. SSL page Specify any ciphers to be used in the connection and, if you are planning to use HTTP over SSL (HTTPS) requests, set the values for HTTPS requests. Response Message Parsing page Set values for the properties that describe the message domain, message set, message type, and message format that the node uses to determine how to parse the response message returned by the Web service. Parser Options page Edit the timing properties on this page to control when and how messages are parsed and validated. Set values for the properties that determine how the request parameters are constructed. Error Handling page Set these properties to determine how an error message returned by the Web service is handled. Advanced page Set these properties to describe the structure and content of the Web service request and response. Validation page Set these properties if you want the MRM parser to validate the body of messages using the dictionary generated from the message set. Security page Identity propagation is turned off by default. To propagate the identity associated with a message, select a security profile on the security tab. SOAPInput node This node processes client SOAP messages, enabling the broker to be a SOAP Web services provider. Properties navigator This displays the node properties. Configure the node by selecting the properties and setting their values. Mandatory properties are marked with an asterisk. Description page If you want to describe the purpose of the node in the message flow, use these fields to enter a short description, a long description, or both. Basic page Choose a WSDL file by dragging and dropping a WSDL on the node, clicking the browse button or typing the file name. Configure the other WSDL properties shown. If the selected WSDL binding uses an HTTP Transport, the properties on the JMS Transport and Message Selectors tabs are disabled. If the selected WSDL binding uses a JMS Transport, the properties on the HTTP Transport tab are disabled. HTTP Transport page Use this page to set the HTTP transport-related properties. The properties on this page are enabled only when the selected WSDL binding in the Basic page uses an HTTP Transport. JMS Transport page Use this page to set the JMS transport-related properties. The properties on this page are enabled only when the selected WSDL binding in the Basic page uses a JMS Transport. Message Selectors page Set the message selector properties. The properties on this page are enabled only when the selected WSDL binding in the Basic page uses a JMS Transport. Advanced page The WDSL-defined SOAP header table shown here is read-only, but you can add, edit, and delete custom headers in the User-defined SOAP headers table. WS-Extensions page If you want to add an XPath expression to the Web Services security table enter it here, with its associated alias value. Input Message Parser page Set values for the properties that describe the message domain, message set, message type, and message format that the node uses to determine how to parse the incoming message. Parser Options page Edit the timing properties on this page to control when and how messages are parsed and validated. Set values for the properties that determine how the request parameters are constructed. Error Handling page Choose whether to send failures during inbound processing to the Failure terminal. Validation page Set the values to determine whether validation of the output message takes place, and what actions are taken if the message fails. Instances page Select the pool from which additional instances are obtained. Choose either the pool associated with the message flow or the pool associated with the node itself. In the latter case, set the number of additional instances to be given. Retry page Choose how to reprocess a message when a failure gets rolled back to the input node. SOAPReply node This node allows SOAP response messages to be sent from the broker back to the originating client in response to a message received by a SOAPInput node. Properties navigator This displays the node properties. Configure the node by selecting the properties and setting their values. Mandatory properties are marked with an asterisk. Description page If you want to describe the purpose of the node in the message flow, use these fields to enter a short description, a long description, or both. Validation page Set the values to determine whether validation of the output message takes place, and what actions are taken if the message fails. --> SOAPRequest node This node sends a synchronous SOAP request, allowing the broker to be a SOAP Web service consumer. Properties navigator This displays the node properties. Configure the node by selecting the properties and setting their values. Mandatory properties are marked with an asterisk. Description page If you want to describe the purpose of the node in the message flow, use these fields to enter a short description, a long description, or both. Basic page Choose a WSDL file by dragging and dropping a WSDL on the node, clicking the browse button or typing the file name. Configure the other WSDL properties shown. If the selected WSDL binding uses an HTTP Transport, the properties on the JMS Transport and Message Delivery tabs are disabled. If the selected WSDL binding uses a JMS Transport, the properties on the HTTP Transport tab are disabled. Binding operation You can change the operation that that should be invoked by changing the value in the following location in the local environment: LocalEnvironment.Destination.SOAP.Request.????? HTTP Transport page Set the HTTP transport-related properties. The properties on this page are enabled only when the selected WSDL binding in the Basic page uses an HTTP Transport. JMS Transport page Set the JMS transport-related properties. The properties on this page are enabled only when the selected WSDL binding in the Basic page uses a JMS Transport. Message Delivery page Set the message delivery properties. The properties on this page are enabled only when the selected WSDL binding in the Basic page uses a JMS Transport. Advanced page The WDSL-defined SOAP header table shown here is read-only, but you can add, edit, and delete custom headers in the User-defined SOAP headers table. WS Extensions page If you want to add an XPath expression to the Web Services security table enter it here, with its associated alias value. Response Message Parser page Set values for the properties that describe the message domain, message set, message type, and message format that the node uses to determine how to parse the incoming message. Parser Options page Edit the timing properties on this page to control when and how messages are parsed and validated. Set values for the properties that determine how the request parameters are constructed. Validation Parser page Set the values to determine whether validation of the output message takes place, and what actions are taken if the message fails. SOAPAsyncRequest node This node is used in conjunction with the SOAPAsyncResponse node to construct a pair of message flows that start a Web service asynchronously. Properties navigator This displays the node properties. Configure the node by selecting the properties and setting their values. Mandatory properties are marked with an asterisk. Description page If you want to describe the purpose of the node in the message flow, use these fields to enter a short description, a long description, or both. Basic page Specify the unique URL fragment that is common to your pair of SOAPAsyncRequest and SOAPAsyncResponse nodes. Configure the WSDL properties shown here. Binding operation You can change the operation that that should be invoked by changing the value in the following location in the local environment: LocalEnvironment.Destination.SOAP.Request.???? HTTP Transport page Set the HTTP transport-related properties. Advanced page The WDSL-defined SOAP header table shown here is read-only, but you can add, edit, and delete custom headers in the User-defined SOAP headers table. WS Extensions page If you want to add an XPath expression to the Web Services security table enter it here, with its associated alias value. SOAPAsyncResponse node This node is used in conjunction with the SOAPAsyncRequest node to construct a pair of message flows that start a Web service asynchronously. Properties navigator This displays the node properties. Configure the node by selecting the properties and setting their values. Mandatory properties are marked with an asterisk. Description page If you want to describe the purpose of the node in the message flow, use these fields to enter a short description, a long description, or both. Basic page Specify the unique URL fragment that is common to your pair of SOAPAsyncRequest and SOAPAsyncResponse nodes. Advanced page If you want to apply a Label prefix, select the Set destination list check box. Instances page Select the pool from which additional instances are obtained. Choose either the pool associated with the message flow or the pool associated with the node itself. In the latter case, set the number of additional instances to be given. Response Message Parsing page Set values for the properties that describe the message domain, message set, message type, and message format that the node uses to determine how to parse the incoming message. Parser Options page Edit the timing properties on this page to control when and how messages are parsed and validated. Set values for the properties that determine how the request parameters are constructed. Validation page Set the values to determine whether validation of the output message takes place, and what actions are taken if the message fails. SoapEnvelope node This node adds a SOAP envelope to an existing message. It is designed to be used with a SOAPExtract node. Properties navigator page This displays the node properties. Configure the node by selecting the properties and setting their values. Mandatory properties are marked with an asterisk. Description page If you want to describe the purpose of the node in the message flow, use these fields to enter a short description, a long description, or both. Basic page Choose whether to create a new SOAP envelope or to use an existing one by entering the XPath location from which the node will copy the SOAP envelope. SoapExtract node This node allows the removal of SOAP envelopes so that the body of a SOAP message is more easily handled. Properties navigator page This displays the node properties. Configure the node by selecting the properties and setting their values. Mandatory properties are marked with an asterisk. Description page If you want to describe the purpose of the node in the message flow, use these fields to enter a short description, a long description, or both. Basic page Specify whether the node should remove the SOAP envelope and, if so, enter details of the route and location to be used for copying it. RegistryLookup node Use this node to access service meta data that resides in the WebSphere Service Registry and Repository (WSRR). Properties navigator This displays the node properties. Configure the node by selecting the properties and setting their values. Mandatory properties are marked with an asterisk. Description page If you want to describe the purpose of the node in the message flow, use these fields to enter a short description, a long description, or both. Basic page Enter values that uniquely identify a WSRR entity. You can also add or edit user-defined properties for the query. EndpointLookup node Use this node to access service meta data that resides in the WebSphere Service Registry and Repository (WSRR). Properties navigator This displays the node properties. Configure the node by selecting the properties and setting their values. Mandatory properties are marked with an asterisk. Description page If you want to describe the purpose of the node in the message flow, use these fields to enter a short description, a long description, or both. Basic page Enter values that uniquely identify a WSRR-defined WSDL service PortType. You can also add or edit user-defined properties for the port. PeopleSoftInput node This node receives input from PeopleSoft applications. Properties navigator This displays the node properties. Configure the node by selecting the properties and setting their values. Mandatory properties are marked with an asterisk. Description page If you want to describe the purpose of the node in the message flow, use these fields to enter a short description, a long description, or both. Basic page Enter the name of an adapter file or click Browse and select from a list of available files. Routing page Choose whether to add the method binding name to the route to label destination list. Input Message Parsing page Set values for the properties that describe the message domain, message set, message type, and message format that the node uses to determine how to parse the incoming message. Transactionality page Specify whether updates are performed in a single transaction as a coordinated message flow or independently. Instances page Select the pool from which additional instances are obtained. Choose either the pool associated with the message flow or the pool associated with the node itself. In the latter case, set the number of additional instances to be given. Retry page Specify how retry processing is handled when a failure is rolled back to the node. If you select Failure, the other properties cannot be set. PeopleSoftRequest node The node requests information from PeopleSoft applications. Properties navigator This displays the node properties. Configure the node by selecting the properties and setting their values. Mandatory properties are marked with an asterisk. Description page If you want to describe the purpose of the node in the message flow, use these fields to enter a short description, a long description, or both. Basic page Enter the name of an adapter file or click Browse and select from a list of available files. Response Message Parsing page Set values for the properties that describe the message domain, message set, message type, and message format that the node uses to determine how to parse the incoming message. Transactionality page Specify whether updates are performed in a single transaction as a coordinated message flow or independently. Request page Enter locations for the business method to be used to perform external actions, and for data retrieval. Result page Enter the location to which the node sends output and choose whether to copy to the local environment. SAPInput node This node receives input SAP applications. Properties navigator This displays the node properties. Configure the node by selecting the properties and setting their values. Mandatory properties are marked with an asterisk. Description page If you want to describe the purpose of the node in the message flow, use these fields to enter a short description, a long description, or both. Basic page Enter the name of an adapter file or click Browse and select from a list of available files. Routing page Choose whether to add the method binding name to the route to label destination list. Input Message Parsing page Set values for the properties that describe the message domain, message set, message type, and message format that the node uses to determine how to parse the incoming message. Transactionality page Specify whether updates are performed in a single transaction, as a coordinated message flow, or independently. Instances page Select the pool from which additional instances are obtained; choose either the pool associated with the message flow or the pool associated with the node itself. In the latter case, set the number of additional instances to be given. Retry page Specify how retry processing is handled when a failure is rolled back to the node. If you select Failure, the other properties cannot be set. SAPRequest node This node requests infromation from SAP applications. Properties navigator This displays the node properties. Configure the node by selecting the properties and setting their values. Mandatory properties are marked with an asterisk. Description page If you want to describe the purpose of the node in the message flow, use these fields to enter a short description, a long description, or both. Basic page Enter the name of an adapter file or click Browse and select from a list of available files. Response Message Parsing page Set values for the properties that describe the message domain, message set, message type, and message format that the node uses to determine how to parse the incoming message. Transactionality page Specify whether updates are performed in a single transaction as a coordinated message flow or independently. Request page Enter locations for the business method to be used to perform external actions, and for data retrieval. Result page Enter the location to which the node sends output and choose whether to copy to the local environment. SiebelInput node This node receives input from Siebel applications. Properties navigator This displays the node properties. Configure the node by selecting the properties and setting their values. Mandatory properties are marked with an asterisk. Description page If you want to describe the purpose of the node in the message flow, use these fields to enter a short description, a long description, or both. Basic page Enter the name of an adapter file or click Browse and select from a list of available files. Routing page Choose whether to add the method binding name to the route to label destination list. Input Message Parsing page Set values for the properties that describe the message domain, message set, message type, and message format that the node uses to determine how to parse the incoming message. Transactionality page Specify whether updates are performed in a single transaction, as a coordinated message flow, or independently. Instances page Select the pool from which additional instances are obtained. Choose either the pool associated with the message flow or the pool associated with the node itself. In the latter case, set the number of additional instances to be given. Retry page Specify how retry processing is handled when a failure is rolled back to the node. If you select Failure, the other properties cannot be set. SiebelRequest node This node requests information from Siebel applications. Properties navigator This displays the node properties. Configure the node by selecting the properties and setting their values. Mandatory properties are marked with an asterisk. Description page If you want to describe the purpose of the node in the message flow, use these fields to enter a short description, a long description, or both. Basic page Enter the name of an adapter file, or click Browse and select from a list of available files. Response Message Parsing page Set values for the properties that describe the message domain, message set, message type, and message format that the node uses to determine how to parse the incoming message. Transactionality page Specify whether updates are performed in a single transaction, as a coordinated message flow, or independently. Request page Enter locations for the business method to be used to perform external actions, and for data retrieval. Result page Enter the location to which the node sends output and choose whether to copy to local environment. TwineBallInput node This node receives input from the TwineBall sample EIS. Use the TwineBallInput node to find out how the WebSphere adapters nodes work. Properties navigator This displays the node properties. Configure the node by selecting the properties and setting their values. Mandatory properties are marked with an asterisk. Description page If you want to describe the purpose of the node in the message flow, use these fields to enter a short description, a long description, or both. Basic page Enter the name of an adapter file or click Browse and select from a list of available files. Routing page Choose whether to add the method binding name to the route to label destination list. Input Message Parsing page Set values for the properties that describe the message domain, message set, message type, and message format that the node uses to determine how to parse the incoming message. Transactionality page Specify whether updates are performed in a single transaction as a coordinated message flow or independently. Instances page Select the pool from which additional instances are obtained. Choose either the pool associated with the message flow or the pool associated with the node itself. In the latter case, set the number of additional instances to be given. Retry page Specify how retry processing is handled when a failure is rolled back to the node. If you select Failure, the other properties cannot be set. TwineBallRequest node This node requests information from the TwineBall sample EIS. Use the TwineBallRequest node to find out how WebSphere adapters nodes work. Properties navigator This displays the node properties. Configure the node by selecting the properties and setting their values. Mandatory properties are marked with an asterisk. Description page If you want to describe the purpose of the node in the message flow, use these fields to enter a short description, a long description, or both. Basic page Enter the name of an adapter file or click Browse and select from a list of available files. Response Message Parsing page Set values for the properties that describe the message domain, message set, message type, and message format that the node uses to determine how to parse the incoming message. Transactionality page Specify whether updates are performed in a single transaction, as a coordinated message flow, or independently. Request page Enter locations for the business method to be used to perform external actions, and for data retrieval. Result page Enter the location to which the node sends output and choose whether to copy to local environment. Filter node This node routes a message according to its content. You can include elements of the input message or message properties in the filter expression. Properties navigator This displays the node properties. Configure the node by selecting the properties and setting their values. Mandatory properties are marked with an asterisk. Description page If you want to describe the purpose of the node in the message flow, use these fields to enter a short description, a long description, or both. Basic page Specify the database to be used and set these properties to configure the Filter node. Label node This node combines with a RouteToLabel node to dynamically route a message based on the message content. Properties navigator This displays the node properties. Configure the node by selecting the properties and setting their values. Mandatory properties are marked with an asterisk. Description page If you want to describe the purpose of the node in the message flow, use these fields to enter a short description, a long description, or both. Basic page Set Label Name to identify a target for a RouteToLabel node. Label Name must not be the same as the name of the instance of the node itself, and it must be unique within the entire message flow in which it appears. Publication node This node filters output messages from a message flow and transmits them to subscribers who have registered an interest in a particular set of topics. Properties navigator This displays the node properties. Configure the node by selecting the properties and setting their values. Mandatory properties are marked with an asterisk. Description page If you want to describe the purpose of the node in the message flow, use these fields to enter a short description, a long description, or both. Basic page Select the Implicit stream naming check box to define whether the name of the WebSphere MQ queue on which the input message was received is to be taken as the stream name. You can also specify the Subscription point for this Publication node. RouteToLabel node This node combines with one or more Label nodes to dynamically route a message based on the message content. You must precede the RouteToLabel node in the message flow with a Compute node. Properties navigator This displays the node properties. Configure the node by selecting the properties and setting their values. Mandatory properties are marked with an asterisk. Description page If you want to describe the purpose of the node in the message flow, use these fields to enter a short description, a long description, or both. Basic page Set Mode to define how the RouteToLabel node removes destinations from the LocalEnvironment associated with the message. Route to Last (the default) causes the last item to be removed from the LocalEnvironment. Route to First, removes the first item. In each case the current message is routed to the Label node identified by labelName in that list item. Route node This node propagates a message to one or more dynamic output terminals. The terminal used depends on a filter expression resolving to true. Filter expressions can incoporate values extracted from elements within the incoming message tree. Properties navigator This displays the node properties. Configure the node by selecting the properties and setting their values. Mandatory properties are marked with an asterisk. Description page If you want to describe the purpose of the node in the message flow, use these fields to enter a short description, a long description, or both. Basic page Set these properties to determine the filter expressions and routing behavior of the node. AggregateControl node This node marks the beginning of a fan-out of requests that are part of an aggregation. Aggregation is an extension of the request/reply application model. Properties navigator This displays the node properties. Configure the node by selecting the properties and setting their values. Mandatory properties are marked with an asterisk. Description page If you want to describe the purpose of the node in the message flow, use these fields to enter a short description, a long description, or both. Basic page Enter a value for Aggregate name to associate the fan-out message flow with the fan-in message flow. This value must be contextually unique within a broker. The default value for Timeout is 0, which means that replies are waited for indefinitely. AggregateReply node This node marks the end of an aggregation fan-in. The node collects replies and combines them into a single compound message. Aggregation is an extension of the request/reply application model. Properties navigator This displays the node properties. Configure the node by selecting the properties and setting their values. Mandatory properties are marked with an asterisk. Description page If you want to describe the purpose of the node in the message flow, use these fields to enter a short description, a long description, or both. Basic page Use Aggregate Name to associate the fan-in message flow with the fan-out message flow, and Unknown Message Timeout to specify how long unindentified messages are held before being propagated to the unknown terminal. Select the Transaction Mode check box to define the transactional characteristics of the message. AggregateRequest node This node records that request messages have been sent. The node also collects information that helps the AggregateReply node to construct the compound response message. Properties navigator This displays the node properties. Configure the node by selecting the properties and setting their values. Mandatory properties are marked with an asterisk. Basic page Enter a value for Folder name. This is used to name a folder in the AggregateReply node's compound message which stores the reply to this request. Description page If you want to describe the purpose of the node in the message flow, use these fields to enter a short description, a long description, or both. Collector node This node groups messages from different sources into a message collection based on rules that you configure in the node. Properties navigator page This displays the node properties. Configure the node by selecting the properties and setting their values. Mandatory properties are marked with an asterisk. Description page If you want to describe the purpose of the node in the message flow, use these fields to enter a short description, a long description, or both. Basic page In the Collection Definition table enter the values for the event handler properties of each dynamic input terminal that you add to the Collector node. Advanced page Use the Persistence Mode field to specify whether messages are stored on the Collector node's queues persistently. The Event Coordination field specifies how messages from the control input terminal are handled for event coordination processing. Mapping node This node constructs one or more new messages and populates them with new information, with modified information from the input message, or with information taken from a database. Properties navigator This displays the node properties. Configure the node by selecting the properties and setting their values. Mandatory properties are marked with an asterisk. Description page If you want to describe the purpose of the node in the message flow, use these fields to enter a short description, a long description, or both. Basic page Set these properties to configure the Mapping node. Data source Enter the name of the data source that is defined to the runtime. If the name is different from the data source name used in the msgmap file, select the Different from data source name in map, use data source specified in flow node property option on the Override Data Source and Schema dialog from Mapping editor. Parser Options page Edit the timing properties on this page to control when and how messages are parsed and validated. Set values for the properties that determine how the request parameters are constructed. Validation page Set these properties if you want the MRM parser to validate the body of messages using the dictionary generated from the message set. Mapping node This node calls the Graphical Data Mapper, which constructs one or more new messages and populates them with new information, modified information from the input message, or information taken from a database. Properties navigator This displays the properties of the Mapping node. Configure the node by selecting the properties and setting their values. Mandatory properties are marked with an asterisk (*). Description page If you want to describe the purpose of the node in the message flow, use these fields to enter a short description, a long description, or both. Basic page Select the graphical data mapping routine that will be called, and the transactional mode for the Mapping node. Select a map for the Mapping node Select a map for the Mapping node. Validation page Set these properties if your graphical data map produces a message in an output domain that supports validation and you want it to validate the body of messages using the dictionary generated from the message set . XSLTransform node This node transforms an XML message to another form of XML message according to the rules provided by an Extensible Stylesheet Language (XSL) stylesheet. Properties navigator This displays the node properties. Configure the node by selecting the properties and setting their values. Mandatory properties are marked with an asterisk. Description page If you want to describe the purpose of the node in the message flow, use these fields to enter a short description, a long description, or both. Stylesheet page Enter the name of the style sheet to be used if the style sheet specification is searched for in the node properties. Advanced page Enter the path where the style sheet is located and the number of parsed style sheets that are stored in this instance of the node. Output Message Parsing page Specify the message domain, set, type, and format associated with the output message, and enter the numeric value of the output character set. Parsing Options page Edit the timing properties on this page to control when and how messages are parsed and validated and whether the XMLNSC compact parser is used for messages in the XMLNS domain. Validation page Set the values to determine whether validation of the output message takes place, and what actions are taken if the message fails. Detail Trace page If you want to trace the actions of the XMLTransformation node, set Detail Trace to On. The default value for the property is Off. Compute node This node constructs one or more new output messages and populates them with new information, with modified information from the input message, or with information taken from a database. Properties navigator This displays the node properties. Configure the node by selecting the properties and setting their values. Mandatory properties are marked with an asterisk. Description page If you want to describe the purpose of the node in the message flow, use these fields to enter a short description, a long description, or both. Basic page Set the properties on this page to make use of data from a database. Parser Options page Edit the timing properties on this page to control when and how messages are parsed and validated. Set values for the properties that determine how the request parameters are constructed. Validation page Set these properties if you want the MRM parser to validate the body of messages using the dictionary generated from the message set. The validation options you set on a Compute node apply only to output messages created. JavaCompute node This node uses Java to filter an incoming message, to change part of an incoming message, or to create a new message. You can add any valid Java code to make use of the Java plug-in API in the Java class that is associated with this node. Properties navigator This displays the node properties. Configure the node by selecting the properties and setting their values. Mandatory properties are marked with an asterisk. Description page If you want to describe the purpose of the node in the message flow, use these fields to enter a short description, a long description, or both. Basic page Select the Java class that you want to associate with this node. If there is no Java class available, close this dialog, right-click the node, then click Open Java and use the wizard to create a new Java class to associate with this node. Parser Options page Edit the timing properties on this page to control when and how messages are parsed and validated and whether the MQRFH2C compact parser is used for messages in the MQRFH2C domain. You can also control when the XMLNSC parser is used to parse messages in the XMLNS domain. Validation page Set these properties if you want the MRM parser to validate the body of messages using the dictionary generated from the message set. The validation options that you set on a JavaCompute node apply only to output messages created. PHPCompute node This node routes and transforms an incoming message, using the PHP scripting language. Properties navigator This displays the node properties. Configure the node by selecting the properties and setting their values. Mandatory properties are marked with an asterisk. Description page If you want to describe the purpose of the node in the message flow, use these fields to enter a short description, a long description, or both. Basic page Set a string containing the name of the PHP script file. Parser Options page Set this property to control whether the XMLNSC compact parser is used for messages in the XMLNS domain. Validation page Set these values to determine whether validation takes place, and the action to be taken if a validation failure occurs. Input node This nodes provides an input terminal for an embedded message flow (a subflow). You can use a subflow for a common task that can be represented by a sequence of message flow nodes. For example, you can create a subflow to increment or decrement a loop counter, or to provide error processing that is common to a number of message flows. Properties navigator Displays the node properties. You configure the node by selecting the properties and setting their values. Mandatory properties are marked with an asterisk. Description page If you want to describe the purpose of the node in the message flow, use these fields to enter a short description, a long description, or both. Output node This node provides an output terminal for an embedded message flow (a subflow). You can use a subflow for a common task that can be represented by a sequence of message flow nodes. For example, you can create a subflow to increment or decrement a loop counter, or to provide error processing that is common to a number of message flows. Properties navigator Displays the node properties. You configure the node by selecting the properties and setting their values. Mandatory properties are marked with an asterisk. Description page If you want to describe the purpose of the node in the message flow, use these fields to enter a short description, a long description, or both. Throw node This node generates an exception within a message flow. You can include a Throw node to force an error path through the message flow if the content of the message contains unexpected data. Properties navigator This displays the node properties. Configure the node by selecting the properties and setting their values. Mandatory properties are marked with an asterisk. Description page If you want to describe the purpose of the node in the message flow, use these fields to enter a short description, a long description, or both. Basic page In Message Catalog, enter the fully-qualified path and file name of the message catalog that contains the message source. In Message Number, enter the error number of the exception being thrown. In Message Text, enter any additional information that you want to be included with the message. Trace node This node generates trace records that can incorporate text, message content, and date and time information, to help you monitor the behavior of the message flow. Include a Trace node to help diagnose errors in your message flow. Properties navigator This displays the node properties. Configure the node by selecting the properties and setting their values. Mandatory properties are marked with an asterisk. Description page If you want to describe the purpose of the node in the message flow, use these fields to enter a short description, a long description, or both. Basic page Set these properties to configure the Trace node. TryCatch node This node provides a special handler for exception processing and prevents exceptions from stopping the processing of the message flow. Properties navigator This displays the node properties. Configure the node by selecting the properties and setting their values. Mandatory properties are marked with an asterisk. Description page If you want to describe the purpose of the node in the message flow, use these fields to enter a short description, a long description, or both. FlowOrder node This node controls the order in which a message is processed by a message flow. Properties navigator This displays the node properties. Configure the node by selecting the properties and setting their values. Mandatory properties are marked with an asterisk. Description page If you want to describe the purpose of the node in the message flow, use these fields to enter a short description, a long description, or both. Passthrough node Use the Passthrough node in a subflow as the first node that follows the Input node to identify the subflow in which it is included. Properties navigator This displays the node properties. Configure the node by selecting the properties and setting their values. Mandatory properties are marked with an asterisk. Description page If you want to describe the purpose of the node in the message flow, use these fields to enter a short description, a long description, or both. Basic page Specify in Label the label or identifier for this node. Enter a value that defines a unique characteristic, for example the version of the subflow in which the node is included. ResetContentDescriptor node This node requests that the message is parsed again, using either a different parser or a different message template. Use this node to reset any combination of message domain, set, type, and format. Properties navigator This displays the node properties. Configure the node by selecting the properties and setting their values. Mandatory properties are marked with an asterisk. Description page If you want to describe the purpose of the node in the message flow, use these fields to enter a short description, a long description, or both. Basic page Set these properties to change the configuration of the message as required. Parsing Options page Edit the timing properties on this page to control when and how messages are parsed and validated. Select one of the XMLNSC options. Validation page Set these properties if you want the MRM parser to validate the body of the message using the dictionary generated from the message set. Database node This node interacts with a database in the specified ODBC data source. Define the nature of the interaction by coding ESQL statements that extracts data from the input message, perhaps transforms it in some way, and assigns the result to a database table. Properties navigator This displays the node properties. Configure the node by selecting the properties and setting their values. Mandatory properties are marked with an asterisk. Description page If you want to describe the purpose of the node in the message flow, use these fields to enter a short description, a long description, or both. Basic page Set these properties to configure the Database node. DataDelete node This node interacts with a database in the specified ODBC data source. Interaction is restricted to deleting one or more rows from a table within the database. Properties navigator This displays the node properties. Configure the node by selecting the properties and setting their values. Mandatory properties are marked with an asterisk. Description page If you want to describe the purpose of the node in the message flow, use these fields to enter a short description, a long description, or both. Basic page Set these properties to configure the DataDelete node. Data source Enter the name of the data source that is defined to the runtime. If the name is different from the data source name used in the msgmap file, select the Different from data source name in map, use data source specified in flow node property option on the Override Data Source and Schema dialog from Mapping editor. DataInsert node This node interacts with a database in the specified ODBC data source. Interaction is restricted to inserting one or more rows into a table within the database. Properties navigator This displays the node properties. Configure the node by selecting the properties and setting their values. Mandatory properties are marked with an asterisk. Description page If you want to describe the purpose of the node in the message flow, use these fields to enter a short description, a long description, or both. Basic page Set these properties to configure the DataInsert node. Data source Enter the name of the data source that is defined to the runtime. If the name is different from the data source name used in the msgmap file, select the Different from data source name in map, use data source specified in flow node property option on the Override Data Source and Schema dialog from Mapping editor. DataUpdate node This node interacts with a database in the specified ODBC data source. Interaction is restricted to updating one or more rows from a table within the database. Properties navigator This displays the node properties. Configure the node by selecting the properties and setting their values. Mandatory properties are marked with an asterisk. Description page If you want to describe the purpose of the node in the message flow, use these fields to enter a short description, a long description, or both. Basic page Set these properties to configure the DataUpdate node. Data source Enter the name of the data source that is defined to the runtime. If the name is different from the data source name used in the msgmap file, select the Different from data source name in map, use data source specified in flow node property option on the Override Data Source and Schema dialog from Mapping editor. Warehouse node This node interacts with a database in the specified ODBC data source. Interaction is restricted to storing all or part of the message in a table within the database. Properties navigator This displays the node properties. Configure the node by selecting the properties and setting their values. Mandatory properties are marked with an asterisk. Description page If you want to describe the purpose of the node in the message flow, use these fields to enter a short description, a long description, or both. Basic page Set these properties to configure the Warehouse node. Data source Enter the name of the data source that is defined to the runtime. If the name is different from the data source name used in the msgmap file, select the Different from data source name in map, use data source specified in flow node property option on the Override Data Source and Schema dialog from Mapping editor. DatabaseRetrieve node This node modifies a messge using information from a database. For example, use the DatabaseRetrieve node to ensure that information in a message is up-to-date by updating it with information from a database. Properties navigator page This displays the node properties. Configure the node by selecting the properties and setting their values. Mandatory properties are marked with an asterisk. Description page If you want to describe the purpose of the node in the message flow, use these fields to enter a short description, a long description, or both. Basic page Set these properties to configure the DatabaseRetrieve node. Data Element Table page Choose the data elements to be used. Validation page Set these properties if you want the MRM parser to validate the body of messages using the dictionary generated from the message set, and choose the failure action to be taken. DatabaseRoute node This node routes messages using information from a database in conjunction with XPath expressions. The node looks up a collection of named column values from a located database row and synchronously applies one or more XPath expressions to those values. Properties navigator page This displays the node properties. Configure the node by selecting the properties and setting their values. Mandatory properties are marked with an asterisk. Description page If you want to describe the purpose of the node in the message flow, use these fields to enter a short description, a long description, or both. Basic page Set these properties to configure the DatabaseRoute node Data Element Table page Specify here the XPath filter expressions and the routing behavior of the node. Extract node This node extracts the contents of the input message that you want to be processed by later nodes in the message flow. You can create a new output message that contains only a subset of the contents of the input message. The Extract node is deprecated. Where possible, replace with a Mapping node. Properties navigator This displays the node properties. Configure the node by selecting the properties and setting their values. Mandatory properties are marked with an asterisk. Description page If you want to describe the purpose of the node in the message flow, use these fields to enter a short description, a long description, or both. Basic page Configure the extract node by identifying the associated mapping routine that is to be run in the node. FileInput node This node receives messages from clients that connect to the broker by creating files in a directory in the broker server's file system. Properties navigator This displays the node properties. Configure the node by selecting the properties and setting their values. Mandatory properties are marked with an asterisk. Description page If you want to describe the purpose of the node in the message flow, use these fields to enter a short description, a long description, or both Basic page Enter the directories and files processed by the FileInput node, together with what to do with any duplicate files encountered. Input Message Parsing page Set values for the properties that the node uses to determine how to parse the incoming message. Parsing Options page Edit the timing properties on this page to control when and how messages are parsed and validated. Select one of the XMLNSC options. Polling page Enter the node's polling interval to determine how frequently the node scans the monitored input directory. Retry page Choose how retry processing is to be performed when a flow fails. Records and Elements page Specify how and to what extent you want your file elements to be processed. Validation page Set these properties if you want the MRM parser to validate the body of messages using the dictionary generated from the message set, and choose the failure action to be taken. FTP page If you want the node to read files from an FTP server, select the FTP checkbox and enter the necessary information. Transactions page Set the transaction mode to say whether the message is to be received under syncpoint. The default is Yes. Instances page Select the pool from which additional instances are obtained; choose either the pool associated with the message flow or the pool associated with the node itself. In the latter case, set the number of additional instances to be given. FileOutput node This node sends messages in file format to services that connect to the broker. The node writes messages to a file in the broker's file system: it can create a new file from a single message or replace an existing file's contents with a message. Properties navigator This displays the node properties. Configure the node by selecting the properties and setting their values. Mandatory properties are marked with an asterisk. Description page If you want to describe the purpose of the node in the message flow, use these fields to enter a short description, a long description, or both. Basic page Enter the directory and file name details of the files created or modified by the node. Request page Enter the location of the data to be written, and any control information overriding the basic panel's directory and file name properties. Validation page Set these values to determine whether validation of the output message takes place, and what actions are taken if the message fails. Records and Elements page Use the Records and Elements page to specify how the FileOutput node handles the message by specifying the properties FTP page If you want the node to transfer files to an FTP server, select the FTP checkbox and enter the necessary information. EmailOutput node This node delivers an e-mail message from a message flow to an SMPT server. It uses the JavaMail API to build and send the e-mail message. Properties navigator This displays the node properties. Configure the node by selecting the properties and setting their values. Mandatory properties are marked with an asterisk. Description page If you want to describe the purpose of the node in the message flow, use these fields to enter a short description, a long description, or both. Basic page Enter the SMPT server and port to which e-mails are sent from this node. Email page Enter the addresses, subject and text of the e-mail. Security page Specify the name of an SMPT runtime property for user name and password. Attachment page Set the properties of the attachment. Validation page Set these properties if you want the MRM parser to validate the body of messages using the dictionary generated from the message set, and choose the failure action to be taken. Validate node This node compares the structure of a message arriving on its input terminal with a message structure definition that you supply when you configure the Validate node. Properties navigator This displays the node properties. Configure the node by selecting the properties and setting their values. Mandatory properties are marked with an asterisk. Description page If you want to describe the purpose of the node in the message flow, use these fields to enter a short description, a long description, or both. Basic page Set these properties to check that a message belongs to a particular domain, message set, or definition. Validation page Set these properties if you want the MRM parser to validate the body of messages using the dictionary generated from the message set. Check node This node compares the structure of a message arriving on its input terminal with a message structure definition that you supply when you configure the Check node. The Check node checks only the message structure definition; it does not check the message body. The Check node is deprecated. Where possible, replace with a Validation node. Properties navigator This displays the node properties. Configure the node by selecting the properties and setting their values. Mandatory properties are marked with an asterisk. Description page If you want to describe the purpose of the node in the message flow, use these fields to enter a short description, a long description, or both. Basic page Set these properties to configure the Check node. TimeoutControl node This node receives an input message that contains a timeout request. The node validates the request, stores the message, and propagates the message (unchanged) to the next node in the message flow. Properties navigator This displays the node properties. Configure the node by selecting the properties and setting their values. Mandatory properties are marked with an asterisk. Description page If you want to describe the purpose of the node in the message flow, use these fields to enter a short description, a long description, or both. Basic page Specify a unique identifier within the broker, ensure that the same identifier is used in the equivalent field in the associated TimeoutNotification node. If you want to change the values for the Timeout Control information location, or the persistence of incoming timeout requests, use the appropriate field. Message page Set these properties if you want to specify the request message location, message domain, message set, message type, or message format. TimeoutNotification node This node provides timeout request message input at regular intervals to a message flow from a WebSphere MQ message queue defined on the broker's queue manager. Properties navigator This displays the node properties. Configure the node by selecting the properties and setting their values. Mandatory properties are marked with an asterisk. Description page If you want to describe the purpose of the node in the message flow, use these fields to enter a short description, a long description, or both. Basic page Specify a unique identifier within the broker. If there is an associated TimeoutControl node, ensure that the same identifier is used in the equivalent field. If you want to change the transactional control of the propagated messages, specify whether there is an associated TimeoutControl node, or change the interval between propagated messages, use the appropriate field. Parser Options page Edit the timing properties on this page to control when and how messages are parsed and validated. Set values for the properties that determine how the request parameters are constructed. Validation page Set these properties if you want the MRM parser to validate the body of messages using the dictionary generated from the message set. SCADAInput node This node receives messages from clients that connect across the WebSphere MQ Telemetry Transport. These SCADA device clients use the MQIsdp protocol to send messages which are converted by the SCADAInput node into a format recognized by IBM Integration Bus. Properties navigator This displays the node properties. Configure the node by selecting the properties and setting their values. Mandatory properties are marked with an asterisk. Description page If you want to describe the purpose of the node in the message flow, use these fields to enter a short description, a long description, or both. Basic page Set the basic properties of the SCADAInput node. Select the Use thread pooling check box only if you expect more than 200 clients to connect. Input Message Parsing page Set properties that describe the message domain, message set, message type, and message format that the node uses to determine how the incoming message is parsed Parser Options page Edit the timing properties on this page to control when and how messages are parsed and validated. Set values for the properties that determine how the request parameters are constructed. Advanced page Set the Transaction Mode to define whether the message is received under syncpoint. Validation page Set these properties if you want the MRM parser to validate the body of messages using the dictionary generated from the message set. SCADAOutput node This node sends a message to a client that connects to the broker by the MQISDP protocol. You would typically use the Publication node to send output to a SCADA client. The SCADAOutput node lets you write your own Publication node. Properties navigator This displays the node properties. Configure the node by selecting the properties and setting their values. Mandatory properties are marked with an asterisk. Description page If you want to describe the purpose of the node in the message flow, use these fields to enter a short description, a long description, or both. Validation page Set these properties if you want the MRM parser to validate the body of messages using the dictionary generated from the message set. Real-timeInput node This node receives messages from clients that connect using the WebSphere MQ Real-time Transport or the WebSphere MQ Multicast Transport, and use JMS application programming interfaces. Properties navigator This displays the node properties. Configure the node by selecting the properties and setting their values. Mandatory properties are marked with an asterisk. Description page If you want to describe the purpose of the node in the message flow, use these fields to enter a short description, a long description, or both. Basic page Set these properties to configure the Real-timeInput node. General Message Options page Edit the properties on this page to control when messages are parsed and validated. Real-timeOptimizedFlow node This node receives messages from clients that connect to the broker using the Webphere MQ Real-time transport or the WebSphere MQ multicast transport, and that use JMS application programming interfaces. Use this node as a complete message flow that provides a high performance publish/subscribe message flow. The actions taken by this node are all internalized, and you cannot influence its operation except by configuring its properties. Properties navigator This displays the node properties. Configure the node by selecting the properties and setting their values. Mandatory properties are marked with an asterisk.
